data.text: Dangers of Cycle Touring Through France, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia, Montengro and Albania?

Hi all, we're cycling from the UK to Greece and will be travelling through France, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia, Montengro and Albania. Will be wild camping throughout and wondered what dangers we could encounter in each country? If anyone has any warnings whether it be animals, landmines or anything else would be a massive help to let us know!

I biked last year through Slovenia, Croatia those countries have good roads, friendly people I experienced no danger in these countries but the weather in July in Croatia is really hot and be prepare for it.
data.author: Jay Chohan

data.text: In Croatia, expect that the highway will be crowded and no one appreciates you, so you have to choose another route or risk taking the highway. I had a great time driving in Albania because the police sent us to drive the highways. Its gonna be an experience there. Have a safe trip.
data.author: Pobješnjeli Maks

data.text: traffic on the main road in Croatia is nasty. try to avoid it.
data.author: Miko Sloper

data.text: we rode the coast a month ago no problems with cars.
data.author: Grant Griffin

data.text: The weather will be hot throughout the whole balcans. In Greece normally free camping is prohibited and you can get a fine, but we do it. Just be careful where you camp if you are in a very touristic place. I don't think you will encounter any problem.
data.author: Kleanthis Kokavesis

data.text: so it's better to camp in a very touristic place or somewhere in more rural areas?
data.author: Marjanovic Jovo

data.text: rural places. If you happen to be in a touristic one, maybe choose an organised camping place if there is available
data.author: Kleanthis Kokavesis

data.text: thank you :)
data.author: Marjanovic Jovo

data.text: Land mines in the forests in Bosnia
data.author: Tom Possert

data.text: Forest fires.... particularly this very dry summer.
data.author: Xavier Bouniol

data.text: I don't know, is it helpful, but after few days in london they stole my bike...🤣
data.author: Andrej Čulk

data.text: Greece will have stray dogs but they’re usually just curious. You could encounter wild boar, who can be agressive, but it’s unlikely. Wild camping’s not really a thing here though so being discreet is sensible. Warmshowers are few and far between but they can be found. Hope this helps. Message me if you need any help in planning Greece.
data.author: Matt Kemp

data.text: Maybe some bad traffic. Central France is lightly populated so you might go hungry if you don't pack food.
data.author: Eric Knudstrup

data.text: My wife and I (ex-pats from US) reside in Albania (Warmshowers hosts in Shkoder) in the winter and pedal the EU and the Balkans in the spring and summer. If you pedal the Balkans in the winter (November through the end of March, you will want to pedal the coastal route down to Greece. If you are pedaling in the warmer months, planning a route through the mountains will be so much more relaxing and so much easier to find locals who will gladly give you permission to put up your tent on their property.
data.author: Chuck Atkinson

data.text: I think I met you at Mi Casa es su Casa hostel in Shkoder in 2018 - you had just stopped by to say "Hi" - were living nearby. I really liked Shkoder & the hostel.
data.author: Roger Noehren

data.text: Yep!
data.author: Chuck Atkinson

data.text: Visit website Welcome in my garden a Register and find place in host garden to pitch tent Free of charge

data.text: Bicycle Travellers why? I think he made a good point that landmines are not somthing you discuss lighthearted on a fb forum
data.author: Wiebrand van der Wijk

data.text: It wasn't light hearted it was genuine concern and an intention to understand local knowledge
data.author: Jeremy Daubeny

data.text: please use your embassy for this kind of information. On fb you wont find a genuine answer alas
data.author: Wiebrand van der Wijk

data.text: North West Italy plains in Summer are hot and humid with plenty of mosquitoes. Not very comfy for camping in general, let alone wild. I would stay closer to the mountains in the lakes region, even if It takes longer because of elevation.
data.author: Grazia Tarantola

data.text: Don’t worry in Albania, you can put your tent anywhere and nothing happens to you .. if you pass by Durazzo I’ll confirm 🤣🤣
data.author: Mandi Yzeiraj

data.text: What a great ride it will be with so many possible routes. I would be tempted to ride down through Italy to Brindisi then take the boat to Greece. The Balkans in summer can be very hot and the traffic bad plus wild dogs a nuisance. But I am sure what ever route you take and where ever you stay that you shall have a great time.
data.author: Alex Maudorn

data.text: I don't think you have to worry so much for some answers you get. Some of these are really unlikely to happen
data.author: Kleanthis Kokavesis

data.text: If that is the roadline in Albania notice the weather is hot like 39°c in road , also that line is close to beach all the way down and there's not to much space for camping, like beach and road directly there, its a nice place and nice people for real.
data.author: Arlind Gecaj

data.text: I have cycled in Bosnia twice and avoided camping in forests with high trees. Portions of the country is still covered in landmines and it's difficult to know where they are in the lower lands due to a huge flood in 2014. I usually camp in low vegetation and next to rivers and abandoned houses. There are plenty of those for obvious reasons. I'm currently on my way to the Balkans again. Awesome part of Europe, enjoy! :D
data.author: Søren Rosenius Olsen

data.text: In Croatia it is preferable to go hopping through islands to island before split as the panorama is better and there is much less traffic
data.author: Raffaele Bianchini

data.text: It has been a few years since our trip from Trieste to Dubrovnik. The coast road was not cycle friendly. Ferry hopping was great. Such beautiful rides and scenery. The ferry company wanted full fare, but we learned from others that friendly truckers took our bikes on the trucks and waited for us at the landing. Have fun.
data.author: Lorry Schiesel

data.text: Amazing ride good luck
data.author: Jacky Tang

data.text: For 10 euros you can sleep at a campsite with warm water
data.author: Eric Vermeulen

data.text: , very similar route to our B plan
data.author: Osian Piercy

data.text: Such a lot of fantastic advice here. Wow!
data.author: Phil Joyce

data.text: In Slovenia and Croatia is forbiden by the law to camp outside official camp sites. But if you keep low or ask owner you will not have problems. Summer is very hot. From 11 h till 16 h is almost impossible to cycle. Traffic depends. In general avoid main turist areas and roads on Fridays and Saturdays. In Slovenia you will find heavy traffic only on the main roads to the border with Croatia. I see that you plan to cross Učka pass in Istria, you will walk a bit because is steep as ....It is better to go a bit north. Over Lika in Croatia you will not have much traffic. In Bosnia, especially in Hercegovina part also. Avoid coastal road in Montenegro, in summer it is a jam. North parth of Albania is a bit tricky to navigate. They are transforming a state road into a highway. Use euro velo. From Vlore to Sarande it will be the ride of the lifetime. In general you will meet a lot of friendly people, who will help you. The food is from very good to awesome.
data.author: Zezo Oz

data.text: The French. You will encounter so many French!
data.author: Leon Mac

data.text: You'll miss the best. Danube route.
data.author: Esperanza Nada P

data.text: Watch out for bears in Slovenia's forests
data.author: Emanuele Vallese

data.text: I just wish you guys the best of luck.
data.author: Freed Fortie

data.text: We felt very welcomed and safe travelling in Montenegro and Albania. In fact in Albania we met one of the most hospitable people
data.author: Plamena Nasheva

data.text: I'm in Italy right now, following the same route as you along the Po river. Mosquitos are a BIG issue when camping. Take anything you can to keep them off of you.
data.author: Nolwenn Vé
